columns.text: The goal of this task is to determine when a lease should appear on the company's balance sheet.

As we have already learned, the company's balance sheet will give us an overview of the company's assets and liabilities. 

For example, when machinery is purchased, we will be able to reflect its value in the assets, as a counterpart, we will also show how we accessed the funds for the purchase. Then we must think about the effect of depreciation and taxes and other items associated with the purchase of the machinery that we must also show in the balance sheet.

Now, if instead of buying the machinery we decide to lease it, then it will depend on the type of lease whether or not the logic of showing on the balance sheet makes sense.

We have two types of lease:

In a **capital (or finance) lease**, ***the risks and rewards are transferred from the Lessor to the lessee***. It is necessary to record all the items related to this lease on the balance sheet. 

There is also the **operating lease**, in which ***the risks and rewards of owning the asset are not transferred to the lessee*** and, therefore, it makes sense to leave the lease transaction off the balance sheet. 

Although as we have learned in this section, this can have a negative impact on correctly interpreting the company's results, debt ratios, for example.

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
textbook.title: Fundamentals of Corporate Finance
